Which prehistoric monument still stands in what is now the English county of Wiltshire?
One of these monuments, Stonehenge, still stands in what is now the English county of Wiltshire. Stonehenge was probably a special gathering place for seasonal ceremonies.
Which village on Orkney is considered the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe?

Skara Brae on Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.
Which impressive hill fort can still be seen in the English county of Dorset?
A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, in the English county of Dorset.
Who led a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC?
Julius Caesar led a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC.
Which Roman Emperor led a successful invasion of Britain in AD 43?
In AD 43 the Emperor Claudius led the Roman army in a new invasion.
Which wall was built by the Emperor Hadrian to keep out the Picts?
Areas of what is now Scotland were never conquered by the Romans, and the Emperor Hadrian built a wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people).
Which Anglo-Saxon burial site in modern Suffolk contained a ship buried under a mound of earth?
The burial place of one of the kings was at Sutton Hoo in modern Suffolk. This king was buried with treasure and armour, all placed in a ship which was then covered by a mound of earth.
Which king united the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms to defeat the Vikings?
The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings.
Who was crowned after the invasion led by William, Duke of Normandy, in 1066?
William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror.
Which book did William I commission to record all the towns, villages, landowners, and animals in England?

William sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book.
Which Scottish leader defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn in 1314?

In Scotland, the English kings were less successful. In 1314 the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn, and Scotland remained unconquered by the English.
Which battle in 1415 during the Hundred Years War was a famous victory for King Henry V’s army?
One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V’s vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French.
Which charter established the idea that even the king was subject to the law?
The result was a charter of rights called the Magna Carta (which means the Great Charter). The Magna Carta established the idea that even the king was subject to the law.
Which famous work by Geoffrey Chaucer is a collection of poems describing a group of pilgrims?

In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury Tales.
Which war was fought between the House of Lancaster and the House of York?

In 1455, a civil war was begun to decide who should be king of England. It was fought between the supporters of two families: the House of Lancaster and the House of York. This war was called the Wars of the Roses.
Which king was killed at the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485?
The war ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485. King Richard III of the House of York was killed in the battle.
Who is considered one of the most famous English playwrights, born in Stratford-upon-Avon?
Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England. He was a playwright and actor and wrote many poems and plays.
Which monarch formed the Church of England after breaking away from the Pope?
When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England. In this new Church, the king, not the Pope, would have the power to appoint bishops and order how people should worship.
Which English queen reigned from 1558 to 1603 and was associated with defeating the Spanish Armada?
Elizabeth became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships).
Who led the parliamentary forces against Charles I and later became Lord Protector?

One of its generals, Oliver Cromwell, was sent to Ireland. After his campaign in Ireland and victory over Charles II at Worcester, Cromwell was recognised as the leader of the new republic. He was given the title of Lord Protector.
Which king was invited back from exile in 1660, an event known as the Restoration?
In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands. He was crowned King Charles II of England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland.
Which act became law in 1679, guaranteeing that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully?
The Habeas Corpus Act became law in 1679. This was a very important piece of legislation which remains relevant today.
Which Scottish mathematician and economist developed ideas about economics, known for ‘The Wealth of Nations’?
Adam Smith developed ideas about economics which are still referred to today.
Which British engineer built the Great Western Railway and many famous bridges?
Brunel was originally from Portsmouth, England. He was an engineer who built tunnels, bridges, railway lines and ships. He was responsible for constructing the Great Western Railway.
Which war did Britain fight between 1853 and 1856, notably covered by media?
From 1853 to 1856, Britain fought with Turkey and France against Russia in the Crimean War. It was the first war to be extensively covered by the media.
Which nurse, regarded as the founder of modern nursing, improved hospital conditions during the Crimean War?

Florence Nightingale was born in Italy to English parents. At the age of 31, she trained as a nurse in Germany. In 1854, she went to Turkey and worked in military hospitals, treating soldiers who were fighting in the Crimean War.
Which act of Parliament greatly increased the number of people with the right to vote?
The Reform Act of 1832 had greatly increased the number of people with the right to vote. The Act also abolished the old pocket and rotten boroughs.
Which movement, formed by campaigners called Chartists, demanded voting rights for the working classes and others without property?
A movement began to demand the vote for the working classes and other people without property. Campaigners, called the Chartists, presented petitions to Parliament.
Which British author, born in 1865, wrote ‘The Jungle Book’ and received the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1907?

Rudyard Kipling was born in India in 1865 and later lived in India, the UK and the USA. Kipling was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1907. Kipling's poems and novels reflected the idea that the British Empire was a force for good.
Which British Prime Minister led the government during most of the Second World War, refusing to surrender to Nazi Germany?
In May 1940 he became Prime Minister. He refused to surrender to the Nazis and was an inspirational leader to the British people in a time of great hardship.
Which British physician discovered penicillin in 1928?
Born in Scotland, Fleming moved to London as a teenager and later qualified as a doctor. He was researching influenza (the ‘flu’) in 1928 when he discovered penicillin.
Which report, published in 1942, proposed ways to fight the five ‘Giant Evils’ and laid the foundations of the modern welfare state?
William Beveridge (later Lord Beveridge) is best known for the 1942 report Social Insurance and Allied Services (known as the Beveridge Report).
Who introduced the Education Act 1944 which enforced free secondary education in England and Wales?
Lord Butler oversaw the introduction of the Education Act 1944 (often called ‘The Butler Act’), which introduced free secondary education in England and Wales.
Which organisation was formed in 1957 by West Germany, France, Belgium, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands?
West Germany, France, Belgium, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands formed the European Economic Community (EEC) in 1957.
Which British Prime Minister first took office in 1979 and was known for her close relationship with US President Ronald Reagan?
Margaret Thatcher worked closely with the United States President, Ronald Reagan, and was one of the first Western leaders to recognise and welcome the changes in the leadership of the Soviet Union.
Which British children’s author wrote ‘Charlie and the Chocolate Factory’ and served in the Royal Air Force during the Second World War?
Roald Dahl was born in Wales to Norwegian parents. He served in the Royal Air Force during the Second World War. It was during the 1940s that he began to publish books and short stories.
Which agreement, signed in 1998, helped bring peace to Northern Ireland?
In Northern Ireland, the Blair government was able to build on the peace process, resulting in the Good Friday Agreement signed in 1998.
Which referendum took place in 2016 and led to the UK officially leaving the EU in 2020?
The Brexit referendum took place in 2016, and the UK officially left the EU in 2020.
How many years ago was Britain permanently separated from the continent by the Channel?
Britain only became permanently separated from the continent by the Channel about 10,000 years ago.
When did the first farmers arrive in Britain?
The first farmers arrived in Britain about 6,000 years ago.
In which county is Stonehenge located?
One of these monuments, Stonehenge, still stands in what is now the English county of Wiltshire. Stonehenge was probably a special gathering place for seasonal ceremonies.
When did people in Britain learn to make bronze, marking the beginning of the Bronze Age?
Around 4,000 years ago, people learned to make bronze. We call this period the Bronze Age.
What was the name given to the tombs in which Bronze Age people buried their dead?
People lived in roundhouses and buried their dead in tombs called round barrows.
Which language family did Iron Age people in Britain speak?
The language they spoke was part of the Celtic language family.
Who was the tribal leader of the Iceni who fought against the Romans?
One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England.
In what year did the Roman army leave Britain, never to return?
The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned.
By about what year were Anglo-Saxon kingdoms established in Britain?
By about AD 600, Anglo-Saxon kingdoms were established in Britain.
Which famous monastery did St Columba found?
St Columba founded a monastery on the island of Iona, off the coast of what is now Scotland.
In which year did the Vikings first visit Britain to raid coastal towns?
The Vikings came from Denmark and Norway. They first visited Britain in AD 789 to raid coastal towns.
What was the name of the area in the east and north of England where many Vikings settled?
Many of the Viking invaders stayed in Britain – especially in the east and north of England, in an area known as the Danelaw.
Which Danish king ruled England for a short period?
Anglo-Saxon kings continued to rule what is now England, except for a short period when there were Danish kings. The first of these was Cnut, also called Canute.
Which statute, introduced by King Edward I in 1284, annexed Wales to the Crown of England?
In 1284 King Edward I of England introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan, which annexed Wales to the Crown of England.
By what year did the English rule an area of Ireland around Dublin known as the Pale?
By 1200, the English ruled an area of Ireland known as the Pale, around Dublin.
Which war, though named otherwise, lasted 116 years between England and France?
English kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years).
Which catastrophic event in 1348 killed about one third of the population of England?
In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death. One third of the population of England died.
In what year did King John agree to the Magna Carta, limiting the king’s power for the first time?
There were few formal limits to the king’s power until 1215. In that year (1215), King John was forced by his noblemen to agree to a number of demands.
Which two Houses were established in the English Parliament during the Middle Ages?

The numbers attending Parliament increased and two separate parts, known as Houses, were established. The nobility, great landowners and bishops sat in the House of Lords. Knights and wealthy people from towns and cities were elected to sit in the House of Commons.
Which poet wrote 'The Bruce' about the Battle of Bannockburn?
A number of poets began to write in the Scots language. One example is John Barbour, who wrote The Bruce about the Battle of Bannockburn.
Which cathedral’s stained glass is a famous example of medieval craftsmanship?
Several of the cathedrals had windows of stained glass. The glass in York Minster is a famous example.
Which export became very important to England’s trade during the Middle Ages?
During this period, England was an important trading nation. English wool became a very important export.
Which king founded the Tudor dynasty after defeating Richard III?
King Richard III of the House of York was killed in the battle and Henry Tudor, the leader of the House of Lancaster, became King Henry VII. Henry was the first king of the House of Tudor.
Who was Henry VIII’s first wife, a Spanish princess?
Catherine of Aragon – Catherine was a Spanish princess. She and Henry had a number of children but only one, Mary, survived.
Which of Henry VIII’s wives was the mother of Elizabeth I?
Anne Boleyn – Anne Boleyn was English. She and Henry had one daughter, Elizabeth.
Which religious movement formed new churches, rejecting the Pope’s authority and reading the Bible in their own languages?
At the same time the Reformation was happening across Europe. This was a movement against the authority of the Pope. The Protestants formed their own churches.
Which book, produced during Edward VI’s reign, is still used in some churches today?
During his reign, the Book of Common Prayer was written to be used in the Church of England. A version of this book is still used in some churches today.
Which devout Catholic queen, known as 'Bloody Mary,' persecuted Protestants?
Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants (for this reason, she became known as ‘Bloody Mary’).
Which queen of Scotland, suspected of involvement in her husband’s murder, was later executed for plotting against Elizabeth I?
When her husband was murdered, Mary was suspected of involvement and fled to England. Mary was eventually executed, accused of plotting against Elizabeth I.
Who succeeded Elizabeth I and became King James I of England, Wales and Ireland?
Elizabeth I never married. When she died in 1603 her heir was her cousin James VI of Scotland. He became King James I of England, Wales and Ireland, King James VI of Scotland
Which translation of the Bible, also known as the Authorised Version, was produced during King James I’s reign?
One achievement of King James’ reign was a new translation of the Bible into English. This translation is known as the ‘King James Version’ or the ‘Authorised Version’.
Which conflict began in 1642, dividing England into Cavaliers and Roundheads?

Civil war between the king and Parliament could not now be avoided and began in 1642. The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).
Which battles, fought during the English Civil War, led to the defeat of the king’s army?
The king’s army was defeated at the Battles of Marston Moor and Naseby. By 1646, it was clear that Parliament had won the war.
Who was recognised as the leader of the new republic and given the title of Lord Protector?
After his campaign in Ireland and victory over Charles II at Worcester, Cromwell was recognised as the leader of the new republic. He was given the title of Lord Protector.
Which event in May 1660 invited Charles II back from exile, restoring the monarchy?
In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands. He was crowned King Charles II. This was called the Restoration.
Which cathedral, destroyed in the Great Fire of London, was rebuilt by Sir Christopher Wren?

The following year, a great fire destroyed much of the city, including many churches and St Paul’s Cathedral. London was rebuilt with a new St Paul’s, which was designed by a famous architect, Sir Christopher Wren.
Which act, passed in 1679, guaranteed that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully?
The Habeas Corpus Act became law in 1679. This was a very important piece of legislation which remains relevant today. Habeas corpus is Latin for ‘you must present the person in court’.
Which pivotal event of 1688 led to James II fleeing to France and William taking the throne?
In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England. James fled to France and William took over the throne, becoming William III.
Which 1690 victory in Ireland is still celebrated by some in Northern Ireland today?
William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690, an event which is still celebrated by some in Northern Ireland today.
Which 1689 document confirmed Parliament’s rights and restricted the king’s power to raise taxes?

The Bill of Rights (1689) confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king’s power. Parliament took control of who could be monarch and declared that the king or queen must be a Protestant.
Which name is still used to refer to the modern Conservative Party, dating back to a main parliamentary group?
There were two main groups in Parliament, known as the Whigs and the Tories. The modern Conservative Party is still sometimes referred to as the Tories.
Which 1707 agreement merged Scotland with England to form the Kingdom of Great Britain?
The Act of Union, known as the Treaty of Union in Scotland, was agreed in 1707, creating the Kingdom of Great Britain.
Which 1745 attempt to put a Stuart king on the throne instead of George II was led by Charles Edward Stuart?

In 1745 there was another attempt to put a Stuart king back on the throne in place of George I’s son, George II. Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie), the grandson of James II, landed in Scotland.
Which battle in 1746 saw Bonnie Prince Charlie defeated by George II’s army?
Charles initially had some successes but was defeated by George II’s army at the Battle of Culloden in 1746.
Which Scottish poet, called 'The Bard,' wrote the song Auld Lang Syne?
Known in Scotland as ‘The Bard’, Robert Burns was a Scottish poet Burns’ best-known work is probably the song Auld Lang Syne.
Which textile pioneer improved the original carding machine and developed horse-driven spinning mills?
He improved the original carding machine. He also developed horse-driven spinning mills that used only one machine. This increased the efficiency of production.
Which Indian-born entrepreneur opened Britain’s first curry house in 1810?
In 1810 he opened the Hindoostane Coffee House in George Street, London. It was the first curry house to open in Britain. Mahomet and his wife also introduced ‘shampooing’
When did it become illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports?
In 1807, it became illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports.
Which act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire?
In 1807, it became illegal to trade slaves and in 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.
Which British Admiral led the navy to victory at the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805?
Britain’s navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805. Admiral Nelson was in charge of the British fleet at Trafalgar and was killed in the battle.
Which major conflict did Britain fight from 1853 to 1856 alongside Turkey and France against Russia?
From 1853 to 1856, Britain fought with Turkey and France against Russia in the Crimean War. It was the first war to be extensively covered by the media.
Which nurse, considered the founder of modern nursing, worked in military hospitals during the Crimean War?
Florence Nightingale was born in Italy to English parents. In 1854, she went to Turkey and worked in military hospitals, treating soldiers who were fighting in the Crimean War.
Which legislation greatly increased the number of people with the right to vote and abolished rotten boroughs?
The Reform Act of 1832 had greatly increased the number of people with the right to vote. The Act also abolished the old pocket and rotten boroughs.
Which movement demanded voting rights for the working classes?
A movement began to demand the vote for the working classes. Campaigners, called the Chartists, presented petitions to Parliament.
Which British Prime Minister famously refused to surrender to Nazi Germany and led the country during the Second World War?
In May 1940 he became Prime Minister. He refused to surrender to the Nazis and was an inspirational leader to the British people in a time of great hardship.
Which Scottish doctor discovered penicillin in 1928?
Born in Scotland, Fleming moved to London as a teenager and later qualified as a doctor. He was researching influenza (the ‘flu’) in 1928 when he discovered penicillin.
Which 1942 publication, also known as the Beveridge Report, outlined fighting the five ‘Giant Evils’ in society?
William Beveridge (later Lord Beveridge) is best known for the 1942 report Social Insurance and Allied Services (known as the Beveridge Report).
Which Conservative politician oversaw the introduction of the Education Act 1944?
Richard Austen Butler (later Lord Butler) became a Conservative MP in 1923. In this role, Lord Butler oversaw the introduction of the Education Act 1944 (often called ‘The Butler Act’).
Which community formed in 1957 by West Germany, France, Belgium, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands did the UK eventually join?

West Germany, France, Belgium, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands formed the European Economic Community (EEC) in 1957. At first the UK did not wish to join the EEC but it eventually did so in 1973.
Who became the first woman Prime Minister of the UK in 1979?
Following the Conservative victory in the General Election in 1979, Margaret Thatcher became the first woman Prime Minister of the UK.
Which British children’s author, born in Wales to Norwegian parents, served in the Royal Air Force and wrote ‘Charlie and the Chocolate Factory’?
Roald Dahl was born in Wales to Norwegian parents. He served in the Royal Air Force during the Second World War. He is most well known for his children’s books.
Which 1998 agreement helped bring about peace in Northern Ireland after decades of conflict?
In Northern Ireland, the Blair government was able to build on the peace process, resulting in the Good Friday Agreement signed in 1998.
Which referendum took place in 2016, leading to the UK officially leaving the EU in 2020?
West Germany, France, Belgium, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands formed the European Economic Community (EEC). The Brexit referendum took place in 2016, and the UK officially left the EU in 2020.
During which centuries did the first Christian communities begin to appear in Britain?
It was during the 3rd and 4th centuries AD that the first Christian communities began to appear in Britain.
By about which year had Anglo-Saxon kingdoms been established in Britain?
Battles were fought against these invaders but, by about AD 600, Anglo-Saxon kingdoms were established in Britain.
By the middle of which century had the last Welsh rebellions been defeated?
By the middle of the 15th century the last Welsh rebellions had been defeated.
By which year did the English rule an area of Ireland known as the Pale, around Dublin?
By 1200, the English ruled an area of Ireland known as the Pale, around Dublin.
In which decade did the English leave France, ending the Hundred Years War?
The English left France in the 1450s.
In which year was the Battle of Agincourt fought?
One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V’s vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French.
What fraction of the population of England died during the Black Death?
One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales. This was one of the worst disasters ever to strike Britain.
By which year were official documents being written in English in England?
By 1400, in England, official documents were being written in English, and English had become the preferred language of the royal court and Parliament.
In which year was it clear that Parliament had won the Civil War against Charles I?
By 1646, it was clear that Parliament had won the war.
In which year was Charles I executed?
He was still unwilling to reach any agreement with Parliament and in 1649 he was executed.
In which year did Oliver Cromwell die?
He was given the title of Lord Protector and ruled until his death in 1658.
In which month and year did Parliament invite Charles II to return from exile?
In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands.
In which year was there a major outbreak of plague in London during Charles II’s reign?
During Charles II’s reign, in 1665, there was a major outbreak of plague in London. Thousands of people died, especially in poorer areas.
Which year saw the Great Fire of London?
The following year, a great fire destroyed much of the city, including many churches and St Paul’s Cathedral.
In which year did the Habeas Corpus Act become law?
The Habeas Corpus Act became law in 1679. Habeas corpus is Latin for ‘you must present the person in court’.
In which year did Charles II die?
Charles II had no legitimate children. He died in 1685 and his brother, James, who was a Roman Catholic, became King James II in England, Wales and Ireland and King James VII of Scotland.
In which year did important Protestants in England invite William of Orange to invade?
In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king.
In which year did the first Jews settle in Britain since the Middle Ages?
The first Jews to come to Britain since the Middle Ages settled in London in 1656.
Between which years did many Huguenots come to Britain from France?
Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came from France. They were Protestants and had been persecuted for their religion.
Between which years was Sir Robert Walpole Prime Minister?
The first man to be called (Prime Minister) was Sir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister from 1721 to 1742.
In which year did Sake Dean Mahomet open the Hindoostane Coffee House in London (the first curry house to open in Britain)?
In 1810 he opened the Hindoostane Coffee House in George Street, London. It was the first curry house to open in Britain.
In which century were the first formal anti-slavery groups set up by the Quakers?
The first formal anti-slavery groups were set up by the Quakers in the late 1700s, and they petitioned Parliament to ban the practice.
In which year did it become illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports?
In 1807, it became illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports, and in 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.
In which year was slavery abolished throughout the British Empire under the Emancipation Act?
In 1807, it became illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports, and in 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.
How many Indian and Chinese workers were employed to replace freed slaves after 1833?
After 1833, 2 million Indian and Chinese workers were employed to replace the freed slaves.
In which year did Britain recognise the American colonies’ independence?
The colonists eventually defeated the British army and Britain recognised the colonies’ independence in 1783.
In which year was there a revolution in France that led to war with Britain?
In 1789, there was a revolution in France and the new French government soon declared war on Britain.
What was the estimated population of the British Empire during Queen Victoria’s reign?
It became the largest empire the world has ever seen, with an estimated population of more than 400 million people.
Approximately how many British citizens left the country during the mass emigration period in the 19th and early 20th centuries?
Between 1853 and 1913, as many as 13 million British citizens left the country.
Approximately how many Russian and Polish Jews came to Britain to escape persecution in the late 19th and early 20th centuries?
Between 1870 and 1914, around 120,000 Russian and Polish Jews came to Britain to escape persecution.
In which year was the law passed limiting women and children to a 10-hour workday?
In 1847, the number of hours that women and children could work was limited by law to 10 hours per day.
In which year did the Great Exhibition open in Hyde Park, London?
In 1851, the Great Exhibition opened in Hyde Park in the Crystal Palace, a huge building made of steel and glass.
Between which years did Britain fight with Turkey and France against Russia in the Crimean War?
From 1853 to 1856, Britain fought with Turkey and France against Russia in the Crimean War.
In which year did Florence Nightingale go to Turkey to work in military hospitals during the Crimean War?
In 1854, she went to Turkey and worked in military hospitals, treating soldiers who were fighting in the Crimean War.
In which year did Florence Nightingale establish the Nightingale Training School for nurses?
In 1860 she established the Nightingale Training School for nurses at St Thomas’ Hospital in London.
In which year did the Reform Act greatly increase the number of people with the right to vote?
The Reform Act of 1832 had greatly increased the number of people with the right to vote.
In which years were the Acts of Parliament passed that gave wives the right to keep their own earnings and property?
Acts of Parliament in 1870 and 1882 gave wives the right to keep their own earnings and property.
In which year did Emmeline Pankhurst help found the Women’s Social and Political Union (WSPU)?
In 1903 she helped found the Women’s Social and Political Union (WSPU).
In which year did women over the age of 30 gain the right to vote in the UK?
In 1918, women over the age of 30 were given voting rights and the right to stand for Parliament, partly in recognition of the contribution women made to the war effort during the First World War.
In which year did women in the UK gain the right to vote at the same age as men, 21?
Shortly before Emmeline’s death in 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.
In which years was the Boer War fought?
The Boer War of 1899 to 1902 made the discussions about the future of the Empire more urgent.
In which year did Rudyard Kipling win the Nobel Prize in Literature?

Kipling was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1907. His books include the 'Just So Stories' and 'The Jungle Book', which continue to be popular today. His poem 'If' has often been voted among the UK's favourite poems. Kipling's poems and novels reflected the idea that the British Empire was a force for good.
On which date was Archduke Franz Ferdinand assassinated, sparking the First World War?
On 28 June 1914, Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria was assassinated. This set off a chain of events leading to the First World War.
How many Indians fought on behalf of Britain in the First World War?

Britain was part of the Allied Powers, which included (amongst others) France, Russia, Japan, Belgium, Serbia – and later, Greece, Italy, Romania and the United States. More than a million Indians fought on behalf of Britain in lots of different countries.
How many Indians were killed fighting for Britain in the First World War?
More than a million Indians fought on behalf of Britain and around 40,000 were killed.
How many British casualties occurred on the first day of the Somme in July 1916?
One battle, the British attack on the Somme in July 1916, resulted in about 60,000 British casualties on the first day alone.
In which year was the Easter Rising in Dublin?
Irish Nationalists were not willing to wait and in 1916 there was an uprising (the Easter Rising) against the British in Dublin.
In which year did Ireland become a republic?
The rest of Ireland became the Irish Free State. It had its own government and became a republic in 1949.
In which year did the world enter the ‘Great Depression’?
However, in 1929, the world entered the ‘Great Depression’ and some parts of the UK suffered mass unemployment.
By how much did car ownership in Britain increase between 1930 and 1939?
Car ownership doubled from 1 million to 2 million between 1930 and 1939.
In which year did Winston Churchill die?
Following his death in 1965, he was given a state funeral.
In which month and year did Winston Churchill become Prime Minister?
In May 1940 he became Prime Minister.
In which year did Hitler invade the Soviet Union?
From the end of June 1940 until the German invasion of the Soviet Union in June 1941, Britain and the Empire stood almost alone against Nazi Germany.
In which year did the Allies comprehensively defeat Germany in the Second World War?

The Allies comprehensively defeated Germany in May 1945. The war against Japan ended in August 1945 when the United States dropped its newly developed atom bombs on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
In which year did Alexander Fleming discover penicillin and win the Nobel Prize, respectively?
He was researching influenza (the flu) in 1928 when he discovered penicillin.
In which year did India and Pakistan gain independence?
In 1947, independence was granted to nine countries, including India, Pakistan and Ceylon (now Sri Lanka).
Between which years did Britain have a Conservative government after the war, following Clement Attlee?
Britain had a Conservative government from 1951 to 1964. The 1950s were a period of economic recovery after the war and increasing prosperity for working people.
In which year was the Beveridge Report published?

The Beveridge report was commissioned by the wartime government in 1941. It recommended that the government should find ways of fighting the five ‘Giant Evils’. The result was a charter of rights called the Magna Carta (which means the Great Charter).
In which year did the Education Act (often called ‘The Butler Act’) introduce free secondary education in England and Wales?
Richard Austen Butler oversaw the introduction of the Education Act 1944 (often called ‘The Butler Act’), which introduced free secondary education in England and Wales.
At what age did Dylan Thomas die?
Dylan Thomas died at the age of 39 in New York. There are several memorials to him in his birthplace, Swansea, including a statue and the Dylan Thomas Centre.
How many people of Indian origin who had been forced to leave Uganda were admitted to Britain in the early 1970s?
Even so, during the early 1970s, Britain admitted 28,000 people of Indian origin who had been forced to leave Uganda.
In which year was the first successful radar test?
The first successful radar test took place in 1935.
In which decade did Alan Turing invent the theoretical Turing machine?
A Turing machine is a theoretical mathematical device invented by Alan Turing [1912–54], a British mathematician, in the 1930s.
In which decade was the jet engine developed by Sir Frank Whittle in Britain?
The jet engine was developed in Britain in the 1930s by Sir Frank Whittle, a British Royal Air Force engineer Officer.
In which decade did Sir Christopher Cockerell invent the hovercraft?
Sir Christopher Cockerell, a British inventor, invented the hovercraft in the 1950s.
In which year did Concorde first fly, and in which year did Concorde begin carrying passengers??
Britain and France developed Concorde, the world’s only supersonic passenger aircraft. It first flew in 1969 and began carrying passengers in 1976.
In which year was the world’s first ‘test-tube baby’ born in Oldham, Lancashire?
IVF (in-vitro fertilisation) therapy for the treatment of infertility was pioneered in Britain. The world’s first ‘test-tube baby’ was born in Oldham, Lancashire in 1978.
In which year did Dolly the sheep become the first mammal successfully cloned by a British team?
In 1996, two British scientists, Sir Ian Wilmot and Keith Campbell, led a team which was the first to succeed in cloning a mammal, Dolly the sheep.
On which date was information successfully transferred via the World Wide Web for the first time?
The inventor of the World Wide Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee, is British. Information was successfully transferred via the web for the first time on 25 December 1990.
In which year was the Northern Ireland Parliament suspended?
In 1972, the Northern Ireland Parliament was suspended and Northern Ireland was directly ruled by the UK government.
How many people lost their lives in the decades after 1969 in the violence in Northern Ireland?
Some 3,000 people lost their lives in the decades after 1969 in the violence in Northern Ireland.
In which year did the Brexit referendum take place?
The Brexit referendum took place in 2016, and the UK officially left the EU in 2020.
In which year did the UK officially leave the EU?
The Brexit referendum took place in 2016, and the UK officially left the EU in 2020.
In which year was Tony Blair first elected as Prime Minister?
In 1997 the Labour Party led by Tony Blair was elected. The Blair government introduced a Scottish Parliament and a Welsh Assembly.
In which year was the Good Friday Agreement signed?
In Northern Ireland, the Blair government was able to build on the peace process, resulting in the Good Friday Agreement signed in 1998.
In which year was the Northern Ireland Assembly elected?
The Northern Ireland Assembly was elected in 1999 but suspended in 2002. It was not reinstated until 2007.
In which year did Gordon Brown lose the general election?
Gordon Brown took over as Prime Minister in 2007. He lost the general election in 2010.
In which year did a coalition government form between the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats?
There was a coalition government from 2010 to 2015. In May 2010, and for the first time in the UK since February 1974, no political party won an overall majority.
How long ago did Britain become permanently separated from the continent by the Channel?
Britain only became permanently separated from the continent by the Channel about 10,000 years ago.
When did the first farmers arrive in Britain?
The first farmers arrived in Britain about 6,000 years ago.
Where is Stonehenge located?
One of these monuments, Stonehenge, still stands in what is now the English county of Wiltshire.
What is Skara Brae?

Skara Brae on Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.
Where is Skara Brae located?

Skara Brae on Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.
How many years ago did people learn to make bronze?
Around 4,000 years ago, people learned to make bronze. We call this period the Bronze Age.
What type of houses did people live in during the Bronze Age?
People lived in roundhouses and buried their dead in tombs called round barrows.
What were the tombs of the Bronze Age called?
People lived in roundhouses and buried their dead in tombs called round barrows.
What age followed the Bronze Age?
The Bronze Age was followed by the Iron Age, when people learned how to make weapons and tools out of iron.
What type of defensive sites were built during the Iron Age?
People still lived in roundhouses, grouped together into larger settlements, and sometimes defended sites called hill forts.
Where can an impressive hill fort still be seen today?
A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, in the English county of Dorset.
In which English county is Maiden Castle located?
A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, in the English county of Dorset.
What language family did the Iron Age people in Britain speak?

The language they spoke was part of the Celtic language family. Similar languages were spoken across Europe in the Iron Age, and related languages are still spoken today in some parts of Wales, Scotland and Ireland.
In which year did Julius Caesar lead a Roman invasion of Britain?
Julius Caesar led a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC. This was unsuccessful and for nearly 100 years Britain remained separate from the Roman Empire.
Who led the successful Roman invasion of Britain in AD 43?
In AD 43 the Emperor Claudius led the Roman army in a new invasion. This time, there was resistance from some of the British tribes but the Romans were successful in occupying almost all of Britain.
Which tribal leader fought against the Romans in eastern England?

One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England. She is still remembered today and there is a statue of her on Westminster Bridge in London, near the Houses of Parliament.
What did Emperor Hadrian build to keep out the Picts?
Areas of what is now Scotland were never conquered by the Romans, and the Emperor Hadrian built a wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people).
Which forts along Hadrian's Wall can still be seen today?

Parts of Hadrian's Wall, including the forts of Housesteads and Vindolanda, can still be seen. It is a popular area for walkers and is a UNESCO (United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization) World Heritage Site.
How long did the Romans remain in Britain?
The Romans remained in Britain for 400 years. They built roads and public buildings, created a structure of law, and introduced new plants and animals.
During which centuries did the first Christian communities begin to appear in Britain?
It was during the 3rd and 4th centuries AD that the first Christian communities began to appear in Britain.
In which year did the Roman army leave Britain?
The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned.
Which tribes invaded Britain after the Roman army left?
Britain was again invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons.
By approximately which year were Anglo-Saxon kingdoms established in Britain?
Battles were fought against these invaders but, by about AD 600, Anglo-Saxon kingdoms were established in Britain.
Where was the burial place of one of the Anglo-Saxon kings?
The burial place of one of the kings was at Sutton Hoo in modern Suffolk.
Who became the first Archbishop of Canterbury?
St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. St Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury.
On which island did St Columba found a monastery?
St Columba founded a monastery on the island of Iona, off the coast of what is now Scotland.
Who became the patron saint of Ireland?
St Patrick became the patron saint of Ireland.
In which year did the Vikings first visit Britain to raid coastal towns?
The Vikings came from Denmark and Norway. They first visited Britain in AD 789 to raid coastal towns and take away goods and slaves.
Which Anglo-Saxon king united the kingdoms in England and defeated the Vikings?
The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings.
What was the area where many Viking settlers stayed in England called?

Many of the Viking invaders stayed in Britain, especially in the east and north of England, in an area known as the Danelaw (many places names there, such as Grimsby and Scunthorpe, come from the Viking languages).
Who was the first Danish king to rule England?
Anglo-Saxon kings continued to rule what is now England, except for a short period when there were Danish kings. The first of these was Cnut, also called Canute.
Which king united the people in the north under the threat of Viking attacks?
In the north, the threat of attack by Vikings had encouraged the people to unite under one king, Kenneth MacAlpin. The term Scotland began to be used to describe that country.
In which year did William, the Duke of Normandy, invade England?
In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings.
Who was defeated by William, the Duke of Normandy, at the Battle of Hastings?
In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle.
What is the name of the embroidery that commemorates the Battle of Hastings?
The battle is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.
What was the name of the comprehensive survey of England ordered by William the Conqueror?

William sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book. It still exists today and gives a picture of society in England just after the Norman Conquest.
Which language influenced the development of English after the Norman Conquest?
Norman French, the language of the new ruling class, influenced the development of the English language as we know it today.
Until what year is the period known as the Middle Ages considered to have lasted?
The period after the Norman Conquest up until about 1485 is called the Middle Ages (or the medieval period).
In which year did King Edward I of England introduce the Statute of Rhuddlan?
In 1284 King Edward I of England introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan, which annexed Wales to the Crown of England.
Which castles were built to maintain English power in Wales?
In 1284 King Edward I of England introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan, which annexed Wales to the Crown of England. Huge castles, including Conwy and Caernarvon, were built to maintain this power.
In which year did the Scottish defeat the English at the Battle of Bannockburn?
In 1314 the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn, and Scotland remained unconquered by the English.
Who led the Scottish to victory at the Battle of Bannockburn?
In 1314 the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn, and Scotland remained unconquered by the English.
By what year did the English rule an area of Ireland known as the Pale?
By 1200, the English ruled an area of Ireland known as the Pale, around Dublin.
What was the area around Dublin ruled by the English called?
By 1200, the English ruled an area of Ireland known as the Pale, around Dublin.
How long did the Hundred Years War actually last?
English kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years).
In which year did the Battle of Agincourt take place?
One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V's vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French.
Which English king led the vastly outnumbered English army to victory at the Battle of Agincourt?
One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V's vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French.
In which decade did the English leave France after the Hundred Years War?
The English left France in the 1450s.
What was the system of land ownership used by the Normans called?
The Normans used a system of land ownership known as feudalism.
What did the king give to his lords in return for help in war?
The king gave land to his lords in return for help in war.
What were most peasants who didn't own their own land called?
Some peasants had their own land but most were serfs.
In which part of Scotland did the feudal system develop?
The same system developed in southern Scotland.
Who owned the land in the north of Scotland and Ireland?
In the north of Scotland and Ireland, land was owned by members of the 'clans' (prominent families).
In which year did the Black Death arrive in Britain?
In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death.
What proportion of England's population died due to the Black Death?
One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales.
What new social class emerged following the Black Death?
New social classes appeared, including owners of large areas of land (later called the gentry), and people left the countryside to live in the towns.
In which year was King John forced by his noblemen to agree to a number of demands (Magna Carta)?

There were few formal limits to the king's power until 1215. In that year (1215), King John was forced by his noblemen to agree to a number of demands. The result was a charter of rights called the Magna Carta (which means the Great Charter).
What was the name of the charter of rights agreed upon by King John and his noblemen?
The result was a charter of rights called the Magna Carta (which means the Great Charter).
Which two Houses were established in the English Parliament?

The nobility, great landowners and bishops sat in the House of Lords. Knights, who were usually smaller landowners, and wealthy people from towns and cities were elected to sit in the House of Commons.
How many Houses did the Scottish Parliament have?
A similar Parliament developed in Scotland. It had three Houses, called Estates: the lords, the commons and the clergy.
What were the three Estates in the Scottish Parliament?
A similar Parliament developed in Scotland. It had three Houses, called Estates: the lords, the commons and the clergy.
How did judges develop 'common law' in England?
In England, judges developed 'common law' by a process of precedence (that is, following previous decisions) and tradition.
How did the legal system develop differently in Scotland compared to England?
In Scotland, the legal system developed slightly differently and laws were 'codified' (that is, written down).
In what year did official documents in England start being written in English?
By 1400, in England, official documents were being written in English, and English had become the preferred language of the royal court and Parliament.
Who wrote The Canterbury Tales?

In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury Tales.
Who was the first person to print books using a printing press in England?
It was one of the first books to be printed by William Caxton, the first person in England to print books using a printing press.
Which Scottish poet wrote The Bruce about the Battle of Bannockburn?
A number of poets began to write in the Scots language. One example is John Barbour, who wrote The Bruce about the Battle of Bannockburn.
Which cathedral is famous for its stained glass windows?
Several of the cathedrals had windows of stained glass, telling stories about the Bible and Christian saints. The glass in York Minster is a famous example.
What was an important export from England during the Middle Ages?
During this period, England was an important trading nation. English wool became a very important export.
In which year did the Wars of the Roses begin?

In 1455, a civil war was begun to decide who should be king of England. This war was called the Wars of the Roses, because the symbol of Lancaster was a red rose and the symbol of York was a white rose.
What was the symbol of the House of Lancaster?

In 1455, a civil war was begun to decide who should be king of England. This war was called the Wars of the Roses, because the symbol of Lancaster was a red rose and the symbol of York was a white rose.
Which battle ended the Wars of the Roses?
The war ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485.
Who became king after Richard III was killed?
The war ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485. King Richard III of the House of York was killed in the battle and Henry Tudor, the leader of the House of Lancaster, became King Henry VII.
What was the symbol of the House of Tudor?
The symbol of the House of Tudor was a red rose with a white rose inside it as a sign that the Houses of York and Lancaster were now allies.
What did Henry VII do to secure his position as king?
He deliberately strengthened the central administration of England and reduced the power of the nobles.
How many times did Henry VIII marry?
Henry VIII was most famous for breaking away from the Church of Rome and marrying six times.
Which of Henry VIII's wives was Spanish?
Catherine of Aragon was a Spanish princess.
Which of Henry VIII's wives gave birth to his son Edward?
Henry married Jane Seymour after Anne's execution. She gave Henry the son he wanted, Edward, but she died shortly after the birth.
Which of Henry VIII's wives was German?
Anne of Cleves was a German princess. Henry married her for political reasons but divorced her soon after.
Which of Henry VIII's wives was a cousin of Anne Boleyn?
Catherine Howard was a cousin of Anne Boleyn. She was also accused of taking lovers and executed.
What did Henry VIII establish when the Pope refused to approve his divorce?
To divorce his first wife, Henry needed the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England.
What was the Reformation a movement against?
This was a movement against the authority of the Pope and the ideas and practices of the Roman Catholic Church.
In which language did Protestants read the Bible instead of Latin?
They read the Bible in their own languages instead of in Latin.
During which century did Protestant ideas gradually gain strength in England, Wales and Scotland?
Protestant ideas gradually gained strength in England, Wales and Scotland during the 16th century.
What act formally united Wales with England during the reign of Henry VIII?
During the reign of Henry VIII, Wales became formally united with England by the Act for the Government of Wales.
Who succeeded Henry VIII as monarch?
Henry VIII was succeeded by his son Edward VI, who was strongly Protestant.
What important religious text was written during Edward VI's reign?
During Edward VI's reign, the Book of Common Prayer was written to be used in the Church of England.
How long did Edward VI rule?
Edward died at the age of 15 after ruling for just over six years, and his half-sister Mary became queen.
What nickname was given to Mary I due to her persecution of Protestants?
Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants (for this reason, she became known as 'Bloody Mary').
Who succeeded Mary I as monarch?
Mary also died after a short reign and the next monarch was her half-sister, Elizabeth, the daughter of Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn.
In which year did the Scottish Parliament abolish the authority of the Pope in Scotland?
In 1560, the predominantly Protestant Scottish Parliament abolished the authority of the Pope in Scotland and Roman Catholic religious services became illegal.
Who was one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada?
Sir Francis Drake, one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada, was one of the founders of England's naval tradition.
What was the name of Sir Francis Drake's ship that circumnavigated the world?
His ship, the Golden Hind, was one of the first to sail right around ('circumnavigate') the world.
In which year did the English defeat the Spanish Armada?

Elizabeth became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.
Which famous playwright is mentioned as part of the Elizabethan period?
The Elizabethan period is also remembered for the richness of its poetry and drama, especially the plays and poems of William Shakespeare.
How old was Mary Stuart when she became queen of Scotland?
She was only a week old when her father died and she became queen. Much of her childhood was spent in France.
Where did Mary Stuart spend much of her childhood?
She was only a week old when her father died and she became queen.  Much of her childhood was spent in France.
To whom did Mary Stuart give her throne when she fled to England?
She gave her throne to her Protestant son, James VI of Scotland.
How long was Mary Stuart kept as a prisoner by Elizabeth I?
Elizabeth suspected Mary of wanting to take over the English throne, and kept her a prisoner for 20 years.
What was Mary Stuart accused of that led to her execution?
Mary was eventually executed, accused of plotting against Elizabeth I.
Where was William Shakespeare born?
Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England.
Which of the following is not a of Shakespeare's most famous plays?
His most famous plays include A Midsummer Night's Dream, Hamlet, Macbeth and Romeo and Juliet.
From which play is the quote 'To be or not to be' taken?
Lines from his plays and poems which are often still quoted include: Once more unto the breach (Henry V). To be or not to be (Hamlet).
Which Shakespeare play contains the line 'All the world's a stage'?
Lines from his plays and poems which are often still quoted include: All the world's a stage (As You Like It).
Which theatre in London is a modern copy of the theatres where Shakespeare's plays were first performed?
The Globe Theatre in London is a modern copy of the theatres in which his plays were first performed.
In which year did Elizabeth I die?
When she died in 1603 her heir was her cousin James VI of Scotland.
Who became King James I of England, Wales and Ireland?
When she died in 1603 her heir was her cousin James VI of Scotland. He became King James I of England, Wales and Ireland but Scotland remained a separate country.
What is the alternative name for the 'King James Version' of the Bible?
This translation is known as the 'King James Version' or the 'Authorised Version'.
Which English monarch first took the title 'King of Ireland'?
Henry VIII took the title 'King of Ireland'.
In which province of Ireland did the English government encourage Scottish and English Protestants to settle?

During the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, many people in Ireland opposed rule by the Protestant government in England. There were a number of rebellions. The English government encouraged Scottish and English Protestants to settle in Ulster, the northern province of Ireland, taking over the land from Catholic landholders.
What were the settlements of Scottish and English Protestants in Ireland known as?
These settlements were known as plantations.
From which part of Scotland did many of the new settlers in Ulster come?
Many of the new settlers came from south-west Scotland and other land was given to companies based in London.
How many years did Charles I rule without Parliament?
For 11 years, he found ways in which to raise money without Parliament's approval but eventually trouble in Scotland meant that he had to recall Parliament.
In which year did Charles I recall Parliament to ask for funds?
In 1640, he recalled Parliament to ask it for funds.
What were the supporters of Parliament called during the Civil War?
The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).
In which year did the Civil War between the king and Parliament begin?
Civil war between the king and Parliament could not now be avoided and began in 1642.
What were the supporters of the king called during the Civil War?
The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).
How many parliamentary leaders did Charles I try to arrest when he entered the House of Commons?
In response, Charles I entered the House of Commons and tried to arrest five parliamentary leaders, but they had been warned and were not there.
In which year was King Charles I executed?
Charles was held prisoner by the parliamentary army. He was still unwilling to reach any agreement with Parliament and in 1649 he was executed.
What was the name given to the republic declared after the execution of Charles I?
England declared itself a republic, called the Commonwealth. It no longer had a monarch.
In which country did Oliver Cromwell establish the authority of the English Parliament with controversial violence?
Cromwell was successful in establishing the authority of the English Parliament but did this with such violence that even today Cromwell remains a controversial figure in Ireland.
At which two battles did Cromwell defeat the Scottish army led by Charles II?
Cromwell defeated this army in the Battles of Dunbar and Worcester.
What title was Oliver Cromwell given as leader of the new republic?
He was given the title of Lord Protector and ruled until his death in 1658.
Who became Lord Protector after Oliver Cromwell's death?
When Cromwell died, his son, Richard, became Lord Protector in his place but was not able to control the army or the government.
How long had Britain been a republic before people began to talk about the need for a king again?

Although Britain had been a republic for 11 years, without Oliver Cromwell there was no clear leader or system of government. Many people in the country wanted stability. People began to talk about the need for a king.
In which month and year was Charles II invited back from exile by Parliament?
In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands.
What was Charles II crowned as?
He was crowned King Charles II of England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland.
In which year was there a major outbreak of plague in London during Charles II's reign?
During Charles II's reign, in 1665, there was a major outbreak of plague in London.
What event occurred in London the year after the plague outbreak of 1665?
During Charles II's reign, in 1665, there was a major outbreak of plague in London. The following year, a great fire destroyed much of the city, including many churches and St Paul's Cathedral.
Who designed the new St Paul's Cathedral after the great fire?
London was rebuilt with a new St Paul's, which was designed by a famous architect, Sir Christopher Wren.
In which year did the Habeas Corpus Act become law?
The Habeas Corpus Act became law in 1679.
What scientific society was formed during Charles II's reign?
During his reign, the Royal Society was formed to promote 'natural knowledge'. This is the oldest surviving scientific society in the world.
Which early member of the Royal Society predicted the return of a famous comet?
Among its early members were Sir Edmund Halley, who successfully predicted the return of the comet now called Halley's Comet.
Where was Isaac Newton born?
Born in Lincolnshire, eastern England, Isaac Newton first became interested in science when he studied at Cambridge University.
What was the title of Isaac Newton's most famous published work?
His most famous published work was Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica ('Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy'), which showed how gravity applied to the whole universe.
Where did Isaac Newton first become interested in science?
Born in Lincolnshire, eastern England, Isaac Newton first became interested in science when he studied at Cambridge University.
In which year did Charles II die?
Charles II had no legitimate children. He died in 1685 and his brother, James, who was a Roman Catholic, became King James II in England, Wales and Ireland and King James VII of Scotland.
What was King James II's religion?
Charles II had no legitimate children. He died in 1685 and his brother, James, who was a Roman Catholic, became King James II in England, Wales and Ireland and King James VII of Scotland.
What position did James II allow Roman Catholics to hold, which was previously forbidden by an Act of Parliament?
James favoured Roman Catholics and allowed them to be army Officers, which an Act of Parliament had forbidden.
What was the religion of James II's two daughters?
However, his heirs were his two daughters, who were both firmly Protestant, and people thought that this meant there would soon be a Protestant monarch again.
In which year did William of Orange invade England?
In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king. When William reached England, there was no resistance.
What title did William of Orange take in Scotland?
James fled to France and William took over the throne, becoming William III in England, Wales and Ireland, and William II of Scotland.
In which battle did William defeat James II in Ireland?
William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690, an event which is still celebrated by some in Northern Ireland today.
Where was the armed rebellion in support of James quickly defeated?
An attempt at an armed rebellion in support of James was quickly defeated at Killiecrankie.
Which Scottish clan was massacred for being late in taking the oath to accept William as king?
All Scottish clans were required formally to accept William as king by taking an oath. The MacDonalds of Glencoe were late in taking the oath and were all killed.
What were James II's supporters known as?
Some continued to believe that James was the rightful king, particularly in Scotland. Some joined him in exile in France; others were secret supporters. James' supporters became known as Jacobites.
In which year was the Declaration of Rights read at the coronation of William and Mary?
The Bill of Rights (1689) confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king's power.
What were the two main groups in Parliament known as?
There were two main groups in Parliament, known as the Whigs and the Tories.
From which year were newspapers allowed to operate without a government licence?
From 1695, newspapers were allowed to operate without a government licence.
In which year did the first Jews since the Middle Ages settle in London?
The first Jews to come to Britain since the Middle Ages settled in London in 1656.
Who were the Protestant refugees that came to Britain between 1680 and 1720?
Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came from France. They were Protestants and had been persecuted for their religion.
In which year was the Act of Union agreed, creating the Kingdom of Great Britain?
The Act of Union, known as the Treaty of Union in Scotland, was agreed in 1707, creating the Kingdom of Great Britain.
Who became king after Queen Anne died in 1714?
When Queen Anne died in 1714, Parliament chose a German, George I, to be the next king, because he was Anne's nearest Protestant relative.
Who was the first man to be called Prime Minister?
The first man to be called this was Sir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister from 1721 to 1742.
In which year did Charles Edward Stuart land in Scotland to attempt to put a Stuart king back on the throne?

In 1745 there was another attempt to put a Stuart king back on the throne in place of George I's son, George II. Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie), the grandson of James II, landed in Scotland.
Who was Charles Edward Stuart trying to replace on the throne?
In 1745 there was another attempt to put a Stuart king back on the throne in place of George I's son, George II.
What was Charles Edward Stuart's nickname?
Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie), the grandson of James II, landed in Scotland.
At which battle was Charles Edward Stuart's army defeated in 1746?
Charles initially had some successes but was defeated by George II's army at the Battle of Culloden in 1746.
What was the name given to the process of evictions and farm destructions in Scotland?
A process began which became known as the 'Highland Clearances'. Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle.
What was the term for the small farms that were destroyed during the Highland Clearances?
Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle.
Where did many Scottish people emigrate to during the early 19th century?
Many Scottish people left for North America at this time.
What is Robert Burns known as in Scotland?
Known in Scotland as 'The Bard', Robert Burns was a Scottish poet.
In which languages did Robert Burns write?
He wrote in the Scots language, English with some Scottish words, and standard English.
What is considered Robert Burns' best-known work?
Burns' best-known work is probably the song Auld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year (or Hogmanay as it is called in Scotland).
What is the Scottish term for New Year's celebrations?
Burns' best-known work is probably the song Auld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year (or Hogmanay as it is called in Scotland).
In which century did the Enlightenment take place?
During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called 'the Enlightenment'.
Which Scottish thinker developed ideas about economics that are still referred to today?
Adam Smith developed ideas about economics which are still referred to today.
Whose ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers?
David Hume's ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers.
What scientific work by James Watt helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution?
Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt's work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.
What important principle of the Enlightenment continues to be important in the UK today?

One of the most important principles of the Enlightenment was that everyone should have the right to their own political and religious beliefs and that the state should not try to dictate to them. This continues to be an important principle in the UK today.
What was the biggest source of employment in Britain before the 18th century?
Before the 18th century, agriculture was the biggest source of employment in Britain.
In which centuries did the Industrial Revolution occur in Britain?
The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries.
What process led to the development of the shipbuilding industry and the railways?
The development of the Bessemer process for the mass production of steel led to the development of the shipbuilding industry and the railways.
Who mapped the coast of Australia?
Captain James Cook mapped the coast of Australia and a few colonies were established there.
Which company gained control of large parts of India?
Britain gained control over Canada, and the East India Company, originally set up to trade, gained control of large parts of India.
Which country was Britain's main rival in overseas expansion and trade?

Trading and settlements overseas sometimes brought Britain into conflict with other countries, particularly France, which was expanding and trading in a similar way in many of the same areas of the world.
What was Richard Arkwright's original profession?
Born in 1732, Arkwright originally trained and worked as a barber. He was able to dye hair and make wigs.
What process did Arkwright improve with his carding machine?
He improved the original carding machine. Carding is the process of preparing fibres for spinning into yarn and fabric.
What type of power did Arkwright initially use for his spinning mills, and what did he use later?
Arkwright initially developed horse-driven spinning mills that used only one machine, which increased the efficiency of production.
In which year did Sake Dean Mahomet open the Hindoostane Coffee House?
In 1810 he opened the Hindoostane Coffee House in George Street, London.
Where was the Hindoostane Coffee House located in London, the first curry house?
In 1810 he opened the Hindoostane Coffee House in George Street, London.
What was significant about the Hindoostane Coffee House in Britain?
It was the first curry house to open in Britain.
What Indian practice did Sake Dean Mahomet and his wife (Jane Daly) introduce to Britain?
Mahomet and his wife also introduced 'shampooing', the Indian art of head massage, to Britain.
By which century was the slave trade a fully established overseas industry?
While slavery was illegal within Britain itself, by the 18th century it was a fully established overseas industry, dominated by Britain and the American colonies.
From which region did slaves primarily come?
Slaves came primarily from West Africa.
Who set up the first formal anti-slavery groups in the late 1700s?
The first formal anti-slavery groups were set up by the Quakers in the late 1700s, and they petitioned Parliament to ban the practice.
Which prominent member of Parliament played an important part in changing the law against slavery?
William Wilberforce, an evangelical Christian and a member of Parliament, also played an important part in changing the law.
In which year did it become illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports?
In 1807, it became illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports, and in 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.
What act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire in 1833?
In 1807, it became illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports, and in 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.
How many Indian and Chinese workers were employed to replace the freed slaves after 1833?
After 1833, 2 million Indian and Chinese workers were employed to replace the freed slaves.
By which decade were there substantial British colonies in North America?
By the 1760s, there were substantial British colonies in North America.
What was the colonists' slogan regarding taxation?
The colonists saw this as an attack on their freedom and said there should be 'no taxation without representation' in the British Parliament.
In which year did 13 American colonies declare their independence?
In 1776, 13 American colonies declared their independence, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments.
In which year did Britain recognize the colonies' independence?
The colonists eventually defeated the British army and Britain recognised the colonies' independence in 1783.
In which year did the revolution in France occur?
In 1789, there was a revolution in France and the new French government soon declared war on Britain.
Who became Emperor of France and continued the war with Britain?
Napoleon, who became Emperor of France, continued the war.
In which year did the Battle of Trafalgar take place?
Britain's navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805.
Who was in charge of the British fleet at the Battle of Trafalgar?
Admiral Nelson was in charge of the British fleet at Trafalgar and was killed in the battle.
Where can Admiral Nelson's ship, HMS Victory, be visited?
His ship, HMS Victory, can be visited in Portsmouth.
In which year did the French Wars end?
In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon by the Duke of Wellington at the Battle of Waterloo.
Who defeated Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo?
In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon by the Duke of Wellington at the Battle of Waterloo.
What was the Duke of Wellington's nickname?
Wellington was known as the Iron Duke and later became Prime Minister.
In which year did Ireland become unified with England, Scotland and Wales?
In 1801, Ireland became unified with England, Scotland and Wales after the Act of Union of 1800. This created the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
What is the Union Flag often called?
This is often called the Union Jack.
Which saint's cross is represented by a red cross on a white ground in the Union Flag?
