They made the first coins to be minted in Britain, some inscribed with the names of Iron Age kings. This marks the beginnings of British history.
In which year did Julius Caesar lead a Roman invasion of Britain?
Julius Caesar led a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC. This was unsuccessful and for nearly 100 years Britain remained separate from the Roman Empire.
Who led the successful Roman invasion of Britain in AD 43?
In AD 43 the Emperor Claudius led the Roman army in a new invasion. This time, there was resistance from some of the British tribes but the Romans were successful in occupying almost all of Britain.
Which tribal leader fought against the Romans in eastern England?

One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England. She is still remembered today and there is a statue of her on Westminster Bridge in London, near the Houses of Parliament.
What did Emperor Hadrian build to keep out the Picts?
Areas of what is now Scotland were never conquered by the Romans, and the Emperor Hadrian built a wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people).
Which forts along Hadrian's Wall can still be seen today?

Parts of Hadrian's Wall, including the forts of Housesteads and Vindolanda, can still be seen. It is a popular area for walkers and is a UNESCO (United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization) World Heritage Site.
How long did the Romans remain in Britain?
The Romans remained in Britain for 400 years. They built roads and public buildings, created a structure of law, and introduced new plants and animals.
When did the first Christian communities begin to appear in Britain?
It was during the 3rd and 4th centuries AD that the first Christian communities began to appear in Britain.
In which year did the Roman army leave Britain?
The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned.
Which tribes invaded Britain after the Roman army left?
Britain was again invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons.
By approximately which year were Anglo-Saxon kingdoms established in Britain?
Battles were fought against these invaders but, by about AD 600, Anglo-Saxon kingdoms were established in Britain.
Where was the burial place of one of the Anglo-Saxon kings?
The burial place of one of the kings was at Sutton Hoo in modern Suffolk.
Who was the most famous Irish missionary who became the patron saint of Ireland?
The most famous of these were St Patrick and St Columba. St Patrick became the patron saint of Ireland.
Where did St Columba found a monastery?
St Columba founded a monastery on the island of Iona, off the coast of what is now Scotland.
Who led the missionaries from Rome to spread Christianity in the south of Britain?
St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. St Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury.
In which year did the Vikings first visit Britain to raid coastal towns?
The Vikings came from Denmark and Norway. They first visited Britain in AD 789 to raid coastal towns and take away goods and slaves.
Which Anglo-Saxon king united the kingdoms and defeated the Vikings?
The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings.
What was the area in England where many Viking settlers stayed called?

Many of the Viking invaders stayed in Britain, especially in the east and north of England, in an area known as the Danelaw (many places names there, such as Grimsby and Scunthorpe, come from the Viking languages).
Who was the first Danish king to rule England?
Anglo-Saxon kings continued to rule what is now England, except for a short period when there were Danish kings. The first of these was Cnut, also called Canute.
Which king united the people in the north under the threat of Viking attacks?
In the north, the threat of attack by Vikings had encouraged the people to unite under one king, Kenneth MacAlpin. The term Scotland began to be used to describe that country.
Who led the invasion of England in 1066?
In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings.
Where was the Battle of Hastings fought?
In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings.
What is the name of the embroidery that commemorates the Battle of Hastings?
The battle is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.
What was the last successful foreign invasion of England?
The Norman Conquest was the last successful foreign invasion of England and led to many changes in government and social structures in England.
What language influenced the development of the English language after the Norman Conquest?
Norman French, the language of the new ruling class, influenced the development of the English language as we know it today.
What was the name of the comprehensive survey of England ordered by William the Conqueror?

William sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book.
Until what year is the period after the Norman Conquest called the Middle Ages?
The period after the Norman Conquest up until about 1485 is called the Middle Ages (or the medieval period).
In which year did King Edward I of England introduce the Statute of Rhuddlan?
In 1284 King Edward I of England introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan, which annexed Wales to the Crown of England.
Which castles were built to maintain English power in Wales?
Huge castles, including Conwy and Caernarvon, were built to maintain this power.
Who led the Scottish to victory against the English at the Battle of Bannockburn?
In 1314 the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn, and Scotland remained unconquered by the English.
What was the area around Dublin ruled by the English in Ireland called?
By 1200, the English ruled an area of Ireland known as the Pale, around Dublin.
What was the name of the war fought between England and France during the Middle Ages?
English kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years).
How long did the Hundred Years War actually last?
English kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years).
In which year did the Battle of Agincourt take place?
One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V's vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French.
Which English king led the vastly outnumbered English army to victory at the Battle of Agincourt?
One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V's vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French.
In which decade did the English leave France after the Hundred Years War?
The English left France in the 1450s.
What system of land ownership did the Normans use?
The Normans used a system of land ownership known as feudalism.
What did the king give to his lords in return for help in war?
The king gave land to his lords in return for help in war.
What were most peasants called in the feudal system?
Some peasants had their own land but most were serfs.
In the north of Scotland and Ireland, who owned the land?
In the north of Scotland and Ireland, land was owned by members of the 'clans' (prominent families).
Where else did the feudal system develop besides England?
The same system developed in southern Scotland.
In which year did the Black Death arrive in Britain?
In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death.
What proportion of England's population died due to the Black Death?
One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales.
What new social class emerged following the Black Death?
New social classes appeared, including owners of large areas of land (later called the gentry), and people left the countryside to live in the towns.
What economic effect did the Black Death have on peasants?
There were labour shortages and peasants began to demand higher wages.
What happened to the area controlled by the English in Ireland after the Black Death?
In Ireland, the Black Death killed many in the Pale and, for a time, the area controlled by the English became smaller.
In which year was King John forced by his noblemen to agree to a number of demands?
There were few formal limits to the king's power until 1215. In that year (1215), King John was forced by his noblemen to agree to a number of demands.
What was the name of the charter of rights agreed upon by King John and his noblemen?
The result was a charter of rights called the Magna Carta (which means the Great Charter).
Which two Houses were established in the English Parliament?

The nobility, great landowners and bishops sat in the House of Lords. Knights, who were usually smaller landowners, and wealthy people from towns and cities were elected to sit in the House of Commons.
How many Houses did the Scottish Parliament have?
A similar Parliament developed in Scotland. It had three Houses, called Estates: the lords, the commons and the clergy.
What were the three Estates in the Scottish Parliament?
A similar Parliament developed in Scotland. It had three Houses, called Estates: the lords, the commons and the clergy.
How did judges develop 'common law' in England?
In England, judges developed 'common law' by a process of precedence (that is, following previous decisions) and tradition.
How did the legal system develop differently in Scotland?
In Scotland, the legal system developed slightly differently and laws were 'codified' (that is, written down).
What two languages combined to form the English language after the Norman Conquest?

After the Norman Conquest, the king and his noblemen had spoken Norman French and the peasants had continued to speak Anglo-Saxon. Gradually these two languages combined to become one English language.
Who wrote The Canterbury Tales?

In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury Tales.
Who was the first person to print books using a printing press in England?
It was one of the first books to be printed by William Caxton, the first person in England to print books using a printing press.
Which language developed in Scotland alongside Gaelic?
In Scotland, many people continued to speak Gaelic and the Scots language also developed.
Who wrote The Bruce about the Battle of Bannockburn?
A number of poets began to write in the Scots language. One example is John Barbour, who wrote The Bruce about the Battle of Bannockburn.
Which cathedral is famous for its stained glass windows?
Several of the cathedrals had windows of stained glass, telling stories about the Bible and Christian saints. The glass in York Minster is a famous example.
What became a very important export from England during the Middle Ages?
During this period, England was an important trading nation. English wool became a very important export.
In which year did the Wars of the Roses begin?
In 1455, a civil war was begun to decide who should be king of England.
What was the symbol of the House of Lancaster?
This war was called the Wars of the Roses, because the symbol of Lancaster was a red rose and the symbol of York was a white rose.
Which battle marked the end of the Wars of the Roses?
The war ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485.
Who became king after the Battle of Bosworth Field?
King Richard III of the House of York was killed in the battle and Henry Tudor, the leader of the House of Lancaster, became King Henry VII.
What was the symbol of the House of Tudor?
The symbol of the House of Tudor was a red rose with a white rose inside it as a sign that the Houses of York and Lancaster were now allies.
What did Henry VII do to secure his position as king?
He deliberately strengthened the central administration of England and reduced the power of the nobles.
How many times did Henry VIII marry?
Henry VIII was most famous for breaking away from the Church of Rome and marrying six times.
Which of Henry VIII's wives was Spanish?
Catherine of Aragon was a Spanish princess. She and Henry had a number of children but only one, Mary, survived.
Which of Henry VIII's wives gave birth to Elizabeth?
Anne Boleyn was English. She and Henry had one daughter, Elizabeth.
Which wife gave Henry VIII the son he wanted?
Henry married Jane after Anne's execution. She gave Henry the son he wanted, Edward, but she died shortly after the birth.
Which of Henry VIII's wives was German?
Anne of Cleves was a German princess. Henry married her for political reasons but divorced her soon after.
Who was the cousin of Anne Boleyn that Henry VIII married?
Catherine Howard was a cousin of Anne Boleyn. She was also accused of taking lovers and executed.
Which of Henry VIII's wives was a widow before marrying him?
Catherine Parr was a widow who married Henry late in his life. She survived him and married again but died soon after.
Why did Henry VIII establish the Church of England?
To divorce his first wife, Henry needed the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England.
What was the Reformation a movement against?
This was a movement against the authority of the Pope and the ideas and practices of the Roman Catholic Church.
In which language did Protestants read the Bible?
They read the Bible in their own languages instead of in Latin.
What act formally united Wales with England during Henry VIII's reign?
During the reign of Henry VIII, Wales became formally united with England by the Act for the Government of Wales.
What was created during Edward VI's reign to be used in the Church of England?
During his reign, the Book of Common Prayer was written to be used in the Church of England.
Who was known as 'Bloody Mary'?
Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants (for this reason, she became known as 'Bloody Mary').
Who succeeded Mary as monarch?
Mary also died after a short reign and the next monarch was her half-sister, Elizabeth, the daughter of Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn.
What did Queen Elizabeth I re-establish as the official Church in England?
She re-established the Church of England as the official Church in England.
In which year did the English defeat the Spanish Armada?

Elizabeth became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.
In which year did the Scottish Parliament abolish the authority of the Pope in Scotland?
In 1560, the predominantly Protestant Scottish Parliament abolished the authority of the Pope in Scotland and Roman Catholic religious services became illegal.
Who was one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada and a founder of England's naval tradition?
Sir Francis Drake, one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada, was one of the founders of England's naval tradition.
What was the name of Sir Francis Drake's ship that circumnavigated the world?
His ship, the Golden Hind, was one of the first to sail right around ('circumnavigate') the world.
Who is mentioned as a notable playwright and poet of the Elizabethan period?
The Elizabethan period is also remembered for the richness of its poetry and drama, especially the plays and poems of William Shakespeare.
How old was Mary Stuart when she became queen of Scotland?
She was only a week old when her father died and she became queen.
Where did Mary Stuart spend much of her childhood?
Much of her childhood was spent in France.
To whom did Mary Stuart give her throne when she fled to England?
She gave her throne to her Protestant son, James VI of Scotland.
How long was Mary Stuart kept as a prisoner by Elizabeth I?
Elizabeth suspected Mary of wanting to take over the English throne, and kept her a prisoner for 20 years.
What was Mary Stuart accused of that led to her execution?
Mary was eventually executed, accused of plotting against Elizabeth I.
Where was William Shakespeare born?
Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England.
From which play is the quote 'To be or not to be' taken?
Lines from his plays and poems which are often still quoted include: Once more unto the breach (Henry V). To be or not to be (Hamlet). A rose by any other name (Romeo and Juliet).
Which Shakespeare play contains the line 'All the world's a stage'?

Lines from his plays and poems which are often still quoted include: Once more unto the breach (Henry V). To be or not to be (Hamlet). A rose by any other name (Romeo and Juliet). All the world's a stage (As You Like It).
Which theatre in London is a modern copy of the theatres where Shakespeare's plays were first performed?
The Globe Theatre in London is a modern copy of the theatres in which his plays were first performed.
Who became the heir to Elizabeth I's throne?
When she died in 1603 her heir was her cousin James VI of Scotland. He became King James I of England, Wales and Ireland but Scotland remained a separate country.
What was King James I's title in Scotland?
When she died in 1603 her heir was her cousin James VI of Scotland. He became King James I of England, Wales and Ireland but Scotland remained a separate country.
What major achievement occurred during King James' reign?
One achievement of King James' reign was a new translation of the Bible into English. This translation is known as the 'King James Version' or the 'Authorised Version'.
What are the two names by which the new Bible translation (written during King James' reign) is known?
This translation is known as the 'King James Version' or the 'Authorised Version'.
Which English monarch first took the title 'King of Ireland'?
Henry VIII took the title 'King of Ireland'.
Who were expected to follow the instructions of the Lord Lieutenants in Dublin?
Henry VIII took the title 'King of Ireland'. English laws were introduced and local leaders were expected to follow the instructions of the Lord Lieutenants in Dublin.
During which monarchs' reigns were there rebellions against Protestant rule in Ireland?
During the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, many people in Ireland opposed rule by the Protestant government in England. There were a number of rebellions.
In which province of Ireland did the English government (Elizabeth I and James I) encourage Scottish and English Protestants to settle?

During the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, many people in Ireland opposed rule by the Protestant government in England. There were a number of rebellions. The English government encouraged Scottish and English Protestants to settle in Ulster, the northern province of Ireland, taking over the land from Catholic landholders.
What were the settlements of Scottish and English Protestants in Ireland known as (during Elizabeth I and James I reigns)?

During the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, many people in Ireland opposed rule by the Protestant government in England. There were a number of rebellions. The English government encouraged Scottish and English Protestants to settle in Ulster, the northern province of Ireland, taking over the land from Catholic landholders. These settlements were known as plantations.
From which part of Scotland did many of the new settlers in Ulster come?

During the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, many people in Ireland opposed rule by the Protestant government in England. There were a number of rebellions. The English government encouraged Scottish and English Protestants to settle in Ulster, the northern province of Ireland, taking over the land from Catholic landholders. Many of the new settlers came from south-west Scotland and other land was given to companies based in London.
How many years did Charles I rule without Parliament?
For 11 years, he found ways in which to raise money without Parliament's approval but eventually trouble in Scotland meant that he had to recall Parliament.
In which year did Charles I recall Parliament to ask for funds?
In 1640, he recalled Parliament to ask it for funds.
What were the supporters of Parliament called during the Civil War?
The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).
In which year did the Civil War between the king and Parliament begin?
Civil war between the king and Parliament could not now be avoided and began in 1642.
What did Charles I try to impose on the Presbyterian Church in Scotland?

Charles I wanted the worship of the Church of England to include more ceremony and introduced a revised Prayer Book. He tried to impose this Prayer Book on the Presbyterian Church in Scotland and this led to serious unrest.
How many parliamentary leaders did Charles I try to arrest in the House of Commons?
In response, Charles I entered the House of Commons and tried to arrest five parliamentary leaders, but they had been warned and were not there.
What were the supporters of the king called during the Civil War?
The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).
At which battles was the king's army defeated?
The king's army was defeated at the Battles of Marston Moor and Naseby.
In which year was Charles I executed?
He was still unwilling to reach any agreement with Parliament and in 1649 he was executed.
What was the name of the republic declared after Charles I's execution?
England declared itself a republic, called the Commonwealth.
Who was sent to Ireland to establish the authority of the English Parliament?

One of its generals, Oliver Cromwell, was sent to Ireland, where the revolt which had begun in 1641 still continued and where there was still a Royalist army. Cromwell was successful in establishing the authority of the English Parliament but did this with such violence that even today Cromwell remains a controversial figure in Ireland.
Where did Charles II famously hide during his escape?
Charles II escaped from Worcester, famously hiding in an oak tree on one occasion, and eventually fled to Europe.
What title was Oliver Cromwell given as leader of the new republic?
He was given the title of Lord Protector and ruled until his death in 1658.
Who became Lord Protector after Oliver Cromwell's death?
When Cromwell died, his son, Richard, became Lord Protector in his place but was not able to control the army or the government.
How long had Britain been a republic before people began talking about the need for a king again?

Although Britain had been a republic for 11 years, without Oliver Cromwell there was no clear leader or system of government. Many people in the country wanted stability. People began to talk about the need for a king.
In which year was Charles II invited back from exile to become king?
In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands. He was crowned King Charles II of England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland.
Which country was Charles II exiled in before becoming king?
In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands.
Which church became the established official Church during Charles II's reign?
The Church of England again became the established official Church. Both Roman Catholics and Puritans were kept out of power.
In which year was there a major outbreak of plague in London during Charles II's reign?
During Charles II's reign, in 1665, there was a major outbreak of plague in London. Thousands of people died, especially in poorer areas.
Who designed the new St Paul's Cathedral after the Great Fire of London?
London was rebuilt with a new St Paul's, which was designed by a famous architect, Sir Christopher Wren.
In which year did the Habeas Corpus Act become law?
The Habeas Corpus Act became law in 1679. This was a very important piece of legislation which remains relevant today.
What scientific society was formed during Charles II's reign?
During his reign, the Royal Society was formed to promote 'natural knowledge'. This is the oldest surviving scientific society in the world.
Which famous scientist was an early member of the Royal Society?
Among its early members were Sir Edmund Halley, who successfully predicted the return of the comet now called Halley's Comet.
Where was Isaac Newton born?
Born in Lincolnshire, eastern England, Isaac Newton first became interested in science when he studied at Cambridge University.
What was the title of Isaac Newton's most famous published work?
His most famous published work was Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica ('Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy'), which showed how gravity applied to the whole universe.
What did Isaac Newton discover about white light?
Newton also discovered that white light is made up of the colours of the rainbow.
Where did Isaac Newton first become interested in science?
Born in Lincolnshire, eastern England, Isaac Newton first became interested in science when he studied at Cambridge University.
In which year did Charles II die?
Charles II had no legitimate children. He died in 1685 and his brother, James, who was a Roman Catholic, became King James II in England, Wales and Ireland and King James VII of Scotland.
Who became King after Charles II's death?
Charles II had no legitimate children. He died in 1685 and his brother, James, who was a Roman Catholic, became King James II in England, Wales and Ireland and King James VII of Scotland.
What was James II's religion?
Charles II had no legitimate children. He died in 1685 and his brother, James, who was a Roman Catholic, became King James II in England, Wales and Ireland and King James VII of Scotland.
What did James II allow Roman Catholics to be, which was previously forbidden by an Act of Parliament?
James favoured Roman Catholics and allowed them to be army Officers, which an Act of Parliament had forbidden.
Who did James II arrest?
He did not seek to reach agreements with Parliament and arrested some of the bishops of the Church of England.
What religion were James II's two daughters?
However, his heirs were his two daughters, who were both firmly Protestant, and people thought that this meant there would soon be a Protestant monarch again.
Who was James II's elder daughter married to?
James II's elder daughter, Mary, was married to her cousin William of Orange, the Protestant ruler of the Netherlands.
In which year did important Protestants in England ask William to invade England?
In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king.
What title did William take in England, Wales and Ireland?
James fled to France and William took over the throne, becoming William III in England, Wales and Ireland, and William II of Scotland.
Why was this event called the 'Glorious Revolution'?

This event was later called the 'Glorious Revolution' because there was no fighting in England and because it guaranteed the power of Parliament, ending the threat of a monarch ruling on his or her own as he or she wished.
Where did James II invade with the help of a French army?
James II wanted to regain the throne and invaded Ireland with the help of a French army.
In which battle did William defeat James II in Ireland?
William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690, an event which is still celebrated by some in Northern Ireland today.
Where was an armed rebellion in support of James quickly defeated?
An attempt at an armed rebellion in support of James was quickly defeated at Killiecrankie.
Which Scottish clan was killed for being late in taking the oath to accept William as king?
The MacDonalds of Glencoe were late in taking the oath and were all killed.
What were James' supporters known as?
James' supporters became known as Jacobites.
What document was read at the coronation of William and Mary?
At the coronation of William and Mary, a Declaration of Rights was read. This confirmed that the king would no longer be able to raise taxes or administer justice without agreement from Parliament.
In which year was the Bill of Rights passed?
The Bill of Rights (1689) confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king's power.
How often did a new Parliament have to be elected according to the new rules?
A new Parliament had to be elected at least every three years (later this became seven years and now it is five years).
What were the two main groups in Parliament called?
There were two main groups in Parliament, known as the Whigs and the Tories.
From which year were newspapers allowed to operate without a government licence?
From 1695, newspapers were allowed to operate without a government licence.
In which year did the first Jews since the Middle Ages settle in London?
The first Jews to come to Britain since the Middle Ages settled in London in 1656.
Who were the Huguenots?
Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came from France. They were Protestants and had been persecuted for their religion.
In which year was the Act of Union agreed?
The Act of Union, known as the Treaty of Union in Scotland, was agreed in 1707, creating the Kingdom of Great Britain.
Who became king after Queen Anne died in 1714?
When Queen Anne died in 1714, Parliament chose a German, George I, to be the next king, because he was Anne's nearest Protestant relative.
Who was the first person to be called Prime Minister?
The most important minister in Parliament became known as the Prime Minister. The first man to be called this was Sir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister from 1721 to 1742.
Who attempted to reclaim the throne from George II in 1745?

In 1745 there was another attempt to put a Stuart king back on the throne in place of George I's son, George II. Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie), the grandson of James II, landed in Scotland.
Where was the decisive battle fought that defeated Charles Edward Stuart's rebellion?
Charles initially had some successes but was defeated by George II's army at the Battle of Culloden in 1746.
What year was the Battle of Culloden fought?
Charles initially had some successes but was defeated by George II's army at the Battle of Culloden in 1746.
What process began after the Battle of Culloden that involved the destruction of small farms?
A process began which became known as the 'Highland Clearances'. Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle.
What were the small farms in Scotland called that were destroyed during the Highland Clearances?
Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle.
Where did many Scottish people emigrate to during the early 19th century?
Many Scottish people left for North America at this time.
What is Robert Burns known as in Scotland?
Known in Scotland as 'The Bard', Robert Burns was a Scottish poet. He wrote in the Scots language, English with some Scottish words, and standard English.
In which languages did Robert Burns write?
He wrote in the Scots language, English with some Scottish words, and standard English.
What is Robert Burns' best-known work?

Known in Scotland as 'The Bard', Robert Burns was a Scottish poet. He wrote in the Scots language, English with some Scottish words, and standard English. Burns' best-known work is probably the song Auld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year (or Hogmanay as it is called in Scotland).
What is the New Year celebration called in Scotland?
Burns' best-known work is probably the song Auld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year (or Hogmanay as it is called in Scotland).
In which century did the Enlightenment take place?
During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called 'the Enlightenment'.
Which Scottish thinker developed influential ideas about economics?
Adam Smith developed ideas about economics which are still referred to today.
Whose ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers?
David Hume's ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers.
What scientific work by James Watt helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution?
Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt's work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.
What was one of the most important principles of the Enlightenment?

One of the most important principles of the Enlightenment was that everyone should have the right to their own political and religious beliefs and that the state should not try to dictate to them. This continues to be an important principle in the UK today.
What was the biggest source of employment in Britain before the 18th century?
Before the 18th century, agriculture was the biggest source of employment in Britain.
In which centuries did the Industrial Revolution occur in Britain?
The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries.
What process led to the development of the shipbuilding industry and railways?
The development of the Bessemer process for the mass production of steel led to the development of the shipbuilding industry and the railways.
Who mapped the coast of Australia?
Captain James Cook mapped the coast of Australia and a few colonies were established there.
Which company gained control of large parts of India?
Britain gained control over Canada, and the East India Company, originally set up to trade, gained control of large parts of India.
What were two products imported from North America and the West Indies?
Sugar and tobacco came from North America and the West Indies.
Which country was Britain's main rival in overseas trade and expansion?

Trading and settlements overseas sometimes brought Britain into conflict with other countries, particularly France, which was expanding and trading in a similar way in many of the same areas of the world.
What was Richard Arkwright's original profession?

Born in 1732, Arkwright originally trained and worked as a barber. He was able to dye hair and make wigs. When wigs became less popular, he started to work in textiles. He improved the original carding machine. Carding is the process of preparing fibres for spinning into yarn and fabric. He also developed horse-driven spinning mills that used only one machine. This increased the efficiency of production. Later, he used the steam engine to power machinery. Arkwright is particularly remembered for the efficient and profitable way that he ran his factories.
What power source did Arkwright later use to power machinery?

Born in 1732, Arkwright originally trained and worked as a barber. He was able to dye hair and make wigs. When wigs became less popular, he started to work in textiles. He improved the original carding machine. Carding is the process of preparing fibres for spinning into yarn and fabric. He also developed horse-driven spinning mills that used only one machine. This increased the efficiency of production. Later, he used the steam engine to power machinery. Arkwright is particularly remembered for the efficient and profitable way that he ran his factories.
Where did Sake Dean Mahomet grow up?
Mahomet grew up in the Bengal region of India.
In which year did Mahomet open the Hindoostane Coffee House?

Mahomet grew up in the Bengal region of India. In 1810 he opened the Hindoostane Coffee House in George Street, London. It was the first curry house to open in Britain.
What was significant about the Hindoostane Coffee House?
In 1810 he opened the Hindoostane Coffee House in George Street, London. It was the first curry house to open in Britain.
What Indian practice did Mahomet and his wife introduce to Britain?

In 1810 Mahomet opened the Hindoostane Coffee House in George Street, London. It was the first curry house to open in Britain. Mahomet and his wife also introduced 'shampooing', the Indian art of head massage, to Britain.
By which century was the slave trade a fully established overseas industry?
While slavery was illegal within Britain itself, by the 18th century it was a fully established overseas industry, dominated by Britain and the American colonies.

After 1833, 2 million Indian and Chinese workers were employed to replace the freed slaves.

Britain's navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805.

In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon by the Duke of Wellington at the Battle of Waterloo. Wellington was known as the Iron Duke and later became Prime Minister.

Between 1853 and 1913, as many as 13 million British citizens left the country.

From 1853 to 1856, Britain fought with Turkey and France against Russia in the Crimean War.

Queen Victoria introduced the Victoria Cross medal during this war. It honours acts of valour by soldiers.

Then, James’s wife had a son. Suddenly, it seemed likely that the next monarch would not be a Protestant after all.

Approximately how many years ago did Britain become permanently separated from the continent by the Channel?
Britain only became permanently separated from the continent by the Channel about 10,000 years ago.
Approximately how many years ago did the first farmers arrive in Britain?
The first farmers arrived in Britain about 6,000 years ago. The ancestors of these first farmers probably came from south-east Europe.
Approximately how many years ago did people learn to make bronze, marking the beginning of the Bronze Age?
Around 4,000 years ago, people learned to make bronze. We call this period the Bronze Age. People lived in roundhouses and buried their dead in tombs called round barrows.
In which year did Julius Caesar lead a Roman invasion of Britain?
Julius Caesar led a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC. This was unsuccessful and for nearly 100 years Britain remained separate from the Roman Empire.
In which year did Emperor Claudius lead the Roman army in a new invasion of Britain?
In AD 43 the Emperor Claudius led the Roman army in a new invasion. This time, there was resistance from some of the British tribes but the Romans were successful in occupying almost all of Britain.
In which century did the first Christian communities begin to appear in Britain?
It was during the 3rd and 4th centuries AD that the first Christian communities began to appear in Britain.
In which century did the first Christian communities continue to appear in Britain?

In which year did the Roman army leave Britain to defend other parts of the Roman Empire?
The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned. Britain was again invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons.
By which year were Anglo-Saxon kingdoms established in Britain?
Battles were fought against these invaders but, by about AD 600, Anglo-Saxon kingdoms were established in Britain. These kingdoms were mainly in what is now England.
In which year did the Vikings first visit Britain to raid coastal towns?
The Vikings came from Denmark and Norway. They first visited Britain in AD 789 to raid coastal towns and take away goods and slaves.
In which year did the Battle of Hastings take place?
In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings.
In which year did the Norman Conquest occur?
The period after the Norman Conquest (1066) up until about 1485 is called the Middle Ages (or the medieval period). It was a time of almost constant war.
Until which year is the Middle Ages period considered to have lasted?
The period after the Norman Conquest (1066) up until about 1485 is called the Middle Ages (or the medieval period). It was a time of almost constant war.
In which year did King Edward I introduce the Statute of Rhuddlan?
In 1284 King Edward I of England introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan, which annexed Wales to the Crown of England. Huge castles, including Conwy and Caernarvon, were built to maintain this power.
By the middle of which century were the last Welsh rebellions defeated?
By the middle of the 15th century the last Welsh rebellions had been defeated. English laws and the English language were introduced.
In which year did the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeat the English at the Battle of Bannockburn?

In Scotland, the English kings were less successful. In 1314 the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn, and Scotland remained unconquered by the English.
By which year did the English rule an area of Ireland known as the Pale?
By 1200, the English ruled an area of Ireland known as the Pale, around Dublin. Some of the important lords in other parts of Ireland accepted the authority of the English king.
In which year did the Battle of Agincourt take place?

In which decade did the English leave France after the Hundred Years War?

In which year did the Black Death arrive in Britain?
In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death. One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales.
In which year was King John forced to agree to the Magna Carta?

There were few formal limits to the king’s power until 1215. In that year (1215), King John was forced by his noblemen to agree to a number of demands. The result was a charter of rights called the Magna Carta (which means the Great Charter). The Magna Carta established the idea that even the king was subject to the law.
By which year were official documents in England being written in English?
By 1400, in England, official documents were being written in English, and English had become the preferred language of the royal court and Parliament.
In which year did Geoffrey Chaucer write a series of poems about a pilgrimage to Canterbury?

In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. It was one of the first books to be printed by William Caxton, the first person in England to print books using a printing press.
In which year did the Wars of the Roses begin?
In 1455, a civil war was begun to decide who should be king of England. This war was called the Wars of the Roses.
In which year did the Battle of Bosworth Field take place, marking the end of the Wars of the Roses?

The Wars of the Roses ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485. King Richard III of the House of York was killed in the battle and Henry Tudor, the leader of the House of Lancaster, became King Henry VII.
In which year did the English defeat the Spanish Armada?

Elizabeth became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.
In which year did the Scottish Parliament abolish the authority of the Pope in Scotland?
In 1560, the predominantly Protestant Scottish Parliament abolished the authority of the Pope in Scotland and Roman Catholic religious services became illegal.
In which year did Elizabeth I die, leading to James VI of Scotland inheriting the throne?
Elizabeth I never married and so had no children of her own to inherit her throne. When she died in 1603 her heir was her cousin James VI of Scotland.
In which year did Charles recall Parliament to ask for funds?
A Scottish army was formed and Charles could not find the money he needed for his own army without the help of Parliament. In 1640, he recalled Parliament to ask it for funds.
By which year was it clear that Parliament had won the war?
By 1646, it was clear that Parliament had won the war.
In which year was Charles executed?
Charles was held prisoner by the parliamentary army. He was still unwilling to reach any agreement with Parliament and in 1649 he was executed.
In which year did the revolt in Ireland begin, which Oliver Cromwell was sent to suppress?
One of its generals, Oliver Cromwell, was sent to Ireland, where the revolt which had begun in 1641 still continued and where there was still a Royalist army.
In which year did Cromwell die, leading to his son Richard becoming Lord Protector?

He was given the title of Lord Protector and ruled until his death in 1658. When Cromwell died, his son, Richard, became Lord Protector in his place but was not able to control the army or the government.
In which year did Parliament invite Charles II to return from exile?
In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands. He was crowned King Charles II of England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland.
In which year did a major outbreak of plague occur in London during Charles II's reign?

In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king. When William reached England, there was no resistance.

William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690, an event which is still celebrated by some in Northern Ireland today. William re-conquered Ireland and James fled back to France.
In which year was the Bill of Rights that confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king's power enacted?

The Bill of Rights (1689) confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king’s power. Parliament took control of who could be monarch and declared that the king or queen must be a Protestant.

From 1695, newspapers were allowed to operate without a government licence. Increasing numbers of newspapers began to be published.

The first Jews to come to Britain since the Middle Ages settled in London in 1656.
In which year was the Act of Union agreed, creating the Kingdom of Great Britain?

The Act of Union, known as the Treaty of Union in Scotland, was therefore agreed in 1707, creating the Kingdom of Great Britain. Although Scotland was no longer an independent country, it kept its own legal and education systems and Presbyterian Church.
In which year did Queen Anne die?
When Queen Anne died in 1714, Parliament chose a German, George I, to be the next king, because he was Anne’s nearest Protestant relative.

The first man to be called this was Sir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister from 1721 to 1742.

In 1745 there was another attempt to put a Stuart king back on the throne in place of George I’s son, George II.
In which year was the Battle of Culloden where Charles Edward Stuart was defeated?

Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie), the grandson of James II, landed in Scotland. He was supported by clansmen from the Scottish highlands and raised an army. In which century did the Enlightenment, characterized by new ideas about politics, philosophy, and science, occur?

During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called ‘the Enlightenment’. Before the 18th century, agriculture was the biggest source of employment in Britain.
In which centuries did the Industrial Revolution occur in Britain?
The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries. Britain was the first country to industrialise on a large scale.

In 1810 Mahomet opened the Hindoostane Coffee House in George Street, London. It was the first curry house to open in Britain. Mahomet and his wife also introduced ‘shampooing’, the Indian art of head massage, to Britain.

In which year did the employment of 2 million Indian and Chinese workers begin to replace freed slaves?

After 1833, 2 million Indian and Chinese workers were employed to replace the freed slaves. They worked on sugar plantations in the Caribbean, in mines in South Africa, on railways in East Africa and in the army in Kenya.

In 1776, 13 American colonies declared their independence, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments. The colonists eventually defeated the British army and Britain recognised the colonies’ independence in 1783.

Napoleon, who became Emperor of France, continued the war. Britain’s navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805.

She reigned until 1901, almost 64 years.

In which year was the law passed that limited the working hours for women and children to 10 hours per day?
In 1847, the number of hours that women and children could work was limited by law to 10 hours per day. Better housing began to be built for workers.

In 1851, the Great Exhibition opened in Hyde Park in the Crystal Palace, a huge building made of steel and glass.

From 1853 to 1856, Britain fought with Turkey and France against Russia in the Crimean War.

In which year did Florence Nightingale go to Turkey to work in military hospitals?

Florence Nightingale was born in Italy to English parents. At the age of 31, she trained as a nurse in Germany. In 1854, she went to Turkey and worked in military hospitals, treating soldiers who were fighting in the Crimean War.
In which year was the Reform Act that increased the number of people with the right to vote enacted?

The Reform Act of 1832 had greatly increased the number of people with the right to vote. The Act also abolished the old pocket and rotten boroughs and more parliamentary seats were given to the towns and cities.
In which year was the second Reform Act passed?

There was a permanent shift of political power from the countryside to the towns but voting was still based on ownership of property. This created many more urban seats in Parliament and reduced the amount of property that people needed to have before they could vote. Until which year did a woman's earnings, property, and money automatically belong to her husband upon marriage?

Until 1870, when a woman got married, her earnings, property and money automatically belonged to her husband. Acts of Parliament in 1870 and 1882 gave wives the right to keep their own earnings and property.

Until 1870, when a woman got married, her earnings, property and money automatically belonged to her husband. Acts of Parliament in 1870 and 1882 gave wives the right to keep their own earnings and property.
In which year was the Women's Franchise League set up by Emmeline Pankhurst?
Emmeline Pankhurst set up the Women’s Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women.
In which year were women over the age of 30 given voting rights and the right to stand for Parliament in the UK?
In 1918, women over the age of 30 were given voting rights and the right to stand for Parliament, partly in recognition of the contribution women made to the war effort during the First World War.

Shortly before Emmeline’s death in 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.
In which year did the Boer War begin?
The Boer War of 1899 to 1902 made the discussions about the future of the Empire more urgent.
In which year did the Boer War end?

In which year was Rudyard Kipling awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature?

Rudyard Kipling wrote books and poems set in both India and the UK. His poems and novels reflected the idea that the British Empire was a force for good. In which year was Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria assassinated?
In 1914, Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria was assassinated. This set off a chain of events leading to the First World War.
In which year did the British attack on the Somme take place?
One battle, the British attack on the Somme in 1916, resulted in about 60,000 British casualties on the first day alone.
On what date did the First World War end?
The First World War ended at 11.00 am on 11th November 1918 with victory for Britain and its allies.

In 1913, the British government promised ‘Home Rule’ for Ireland.

Irland became a republic in 1949.
In which year did the world enter the 'Great Depression'?
However, in 1929, the world entered the ‘Great Depression’ and some parts of the UK suffered mass unemployment.

In which year did the BBC begin the world’s first regular television service?

In which year did Churchill become Prime Minister?
Churchill was a soldier and journalist. In May 1940 he became Prime Minister.
In which year did he lose the General Election?
He lost the General Election in 1945 but returned as Prime Minister in 1951.
In which year did Churchill return as Prime Minister?
Churchill lost the General Election in 1945 but returned as Prime Minister in 1951.
In which year did Churchill stand down at the General Election?
Winston Churchill was an MP until he stood down at the 1964 General Election. Following his death in 1965, he was given a state funeral.
In which year did Churchill pass away and receive a state funeral?

In which year did Adolf Hitler come to power in Germany?

Adolf Hitler came to power in Germany in 1933. He believed that the conditions imposed on Germany by the Allies after the First World War were unfair. He also wanted to conquer more land for the German people.
In which year did Hitler invade Poland?

However, when Hitler invaded Poland in 1939, Britain and France declared war in order to stop his aggression. The war was initially fought between the Axis powers (fascist Germany and Italy and the Empire of Japan) and the Allies.
In which year did the rescue operation from the beaches around Dunkirk take place?
Many civilian volunteers in small pleasure and fishing boats from Britain helped the Navy to rescue more than 300,000 men from the beaches around Dunkirk in 1940.
In which year did the Battle of Britain take place?

The Germans waged an air campaign against Britain, but the British resisted with their fighter planes and eventually won the crucial aerial battle against the Germans, called ‘the Battle of Britain’, in the summer of 1940.
In which year did the United States enter the war after the bombing of Pearl Harbour?
The United States entered the war when the Japanese bombed its naval base at Pearl Harbour in December 1941.
On which date did the allied forces land in Normandy, an event known as 'D-Day'?
On 6 June 1944, allied forces landed in Normandy (this event is often referred to as ‘D-Day’).
In which year did the United States drop atom bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, ending the war against Japan?
The war against Japan ended in August 1945 when the United States dropped its newly developed atom bombs on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
In which year did Alexander Fleming discover penicillin?

Alexander Fleming born in Scotland, Fleming moved to London as a teenager and later qualified as a doctor. He was researching influenza (the ‘flu’) in 1928 when he discovered penicillin. Alexander Fleming won the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 1945.
In which year did Alexander Fleming win the Nobel Prize in Medicine?

Alexander Fleming born in Scotland, Fleming moved to London as a teenager and later qualified as a doctor. He was researching influenza (the ‘flu’) in 1928 when he discovered penicillin. Alexander Fleming won the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 1945.
In which year did the British people elect a Labour government with Clement Atlee as Prime Minister?
In 1945 the British people elected a Labour government. The new Prime Minister was Clement Atlee, who promised to introduce the welfare state outlined in the Beveridge Report.
In which year was the National Health Service (NHS) established?

In 1948, Aneurin (Nye) Bevan, the Minister for Health, led the establishment of the National Health Service (NHS), which guaranteed a minimum standard of health care for all, free at the point of use.
In which year was independence granted to India, Pakistan, and Ceylon?

In 1947, independence was granted to nine countries, including India, Pakistan and Ceylon (now Sri Lanka). Other colonies in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific achieved independence over the next 20 years.
In which decade did Harold Macmillan deliver his 'wind of change' speech?

In which year did the Labour Party win the election, leading to Clement Attlee becoming Prime Minister?
Clement Attlee was Winston Churchill’s Deputy Prime Minister in the wartime coalition government and became Prime Minister after the Labour Party won the 1945 election.
In which year was the Beveridge Report, officially known as Social Insurance and Allied Services, published?

William Beveridge (later Lord Beveridge) was a British economist and social reformer. He served briefly as a Liberal MP and was subsequently the leader of the Liberals in the House of Lords but is best known for the 1942 report Social Insurance and Allied Services (known as the Beveridge Report).
In which year was the Education Act, also known as 'The Butler Act', introduced?
Sir Butler oversaw the introduction of the Education Act 1944 (often called ‘The Butler Act’), which introduced free secondary education in England and Wales.
In which decade was the period known as 'the Swinging Sixties'?
The decade of the 1960s was a period of significant social change. It was known as ‘the Swinging Sixties’. There was growth in British fashion, cinema and popular music.

In 1932 he made the first television broadcast between London and Glasgow.
In which year did the first successful radar test take place?
Radar was developed by Scotsman Sir Robert Watson-Watt, who proposed that enemy aircraft could be detected by radio waves. The first successful radar test took place in 1935.
On which date was information successfully transferred via the web for the first time?
The inventor of the World Wide Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee, is British. Information was successfully transferred via the web for the first time on 25 December 1990.
In which year was the Northern Ireland Parliament suspended and Northern Ireland placed under direct rule by the UK government?
In 1972, the Northern Ireland Parliament was suspended and Northern Ireland was directly ruled by the UK government.

Some 3,000 people lost their lives in the decades after 1969 in the violence in Northern Ireland.
In which year was the European Economic Community (EEC) formed?
West Germany, France, Belgium, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands formed the European Economic Community (EEC) in 1957.
In which year did the UK join the EEC?
At first the UK did not wish to join the EEC but it eventually did so in 1973.
In which year was Margaret Thatcher elected as a Conservative MP?
Margaret Thatcher was elected as a Conservative MP in 1959 and became a cabinet minister in 1970 as the Secretary of State for Education and Science.
In which year did Margaret Thatcher become a cabinet minister as the Secretary of State for Education and Science?
Margaret Thatcher was elected as a Conservative MP in 1959 and became a cabinet minister in 1970 as the Secretary of State for Education and Science.
In which year was Margaret Thatcher elected as Leader of the Conservative Party?
In 1975 Margaret Thatcher was elected as Leader of the Conservative Party and so became Leader of the Opposition.
In which year did Margaret Thatcher become the first woman Prime Minister of the UK?
Following the Conservative victory in the General Election in 1979, Margaret Thatcher became the first woman Prime Minister of the UK.
In which year did Margaret Thatcher leave office as Prime Minister?
Margaret Thatcher was the longestserving Prime Minister of the 20th century, remaining in Office until 1990.
